title: Paris attack: Police worker who killed four 'supported Charlie Hebdo massacre'

The police worker who killed four colleagues at the force's headquarters in Paris has previously shown support for the Charlie Hebdo massacre, it has been claimed.

Mickael Harpon, 45, stabbed four officers to death on October 3 before being shot dead.

The computer expert carried out the frenzied attack in France and had become "incoherent" and was displaying "unusual and agitated behaviour" his wife Iham said.

Prior to last Thursday's killings, Harpon had "supported the Charlie Hebdo killings" which left 12 dead four years ago.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

(Image: BFMTV)

He "agreed with certain atrocities committed in the name of that religion" and defended the attacks in 2015, anti-terror prosecutor Jean-Francois Ricard said.

He worked at the police HQ for "several years" and converted to Islam ten years ago, the official confirmed.

Harpon was shot dead following the rampage inside the historic Paris Police Prefecture, next door to Notre Dame Cathedral, on Thursday afternoon.

His wife said he suffered a "dementia attack" the night before taking his co-workers' lives.

(Image: Getty)

Following a raid on the couple’s flat in the Paris suburb on Gonesse, anti-terrorist prosecutors in the French capital have opened an enquiry for ‘assassination of a public servant in relation to a terrorist enterprise.'

Harpon, who originally came from the French overseas territory of Martinique, stabbed a senior officer and three guardians of the peace to death.

They have been identified as General Damien E., 50, Brice L., 38, Anthony L., also 38, and Aurelia T., 39.

Colleagues described Harpon as a previously trusted employee who had full security clearance to work in the Prefecture’s IT department.

(Image: Getty)

He was said to have praised the masked gunmen who stormed the Paris offices of satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo four years ago.

The newspaper's tone is known to be rebellious, anti-religious and left-wing, having published several articles about the extreme right and poking fun at several different religions.

"In the light of the evidence gathered by criminal investigators at this stage of the inquiry, the national anti-terror prosecutor unit this evening took up the investigation into the events committed yesterday at the police prefecture", a Paris prosecutor's official said.
description: Mickael Harpon, a computer expert within the French force, displayed "unusual and agitated behaviour" before the attack
